verses.text: In the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, when wine was before him, I took the wine and gave it to the king. Now I had never been sad in his presence before.
verses.comment: The month of Nisan corresponds to March-April. Nehemiah, the cupbearer, shows deep emotion, which was risky in the king’s court.

verses.text: So the king said to me, 'Why is your face sad, since you are not sick? This is nothing but sadness of heart.' Then I was greatly afraid.
verses.comment: Showing sadness was dangerous before Persian royalty (compare Esther 4:2). Nehemiah’s fear shows the risk involved.

verses.text: I said to the king, 'May the king live forever! Why should my face not be sad, when the city, the place of my fathers’ graves, lies in ruins, and its gates have been destroyed by fire?'
verses.comment: Nehemiah tactfully appeals to the king's sympathy by mentioning his ancestors’ graves, showing reverence and wisdom.

verses.text: Then the king said to me, 'What are you requesting?' So I prayed to the God of heaven.
verses.comment: Nehemiah’s brief prayer before acting shows reliance on God even in quick, urgent moments.

verses.text: And I said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, and if your servant has found favor in your sight, send me to Judah, to the city of my fathers' graves, that I may rebuild it.'
verses.comment: Nehemiah is granted favor (Heb. chen), echoing divine favor shown to key biblical leaders (see also Luke 1:30).

verses.text: And the king said to me (the queen was sitting beside him), 'How long will your journey be, and when will you return?' So it pleased the king to send me, and I set him a time.
verses.comment: Mention of the queen adds authenticity. Nehemiah provides a time—accountability before authority matters.

verses.text: I also said to the king, 'If it pleases the king, let letters be given me to the governors of the province Beyond the River, that they may allow me to pass through until I come to Judah,'
verses.comment: Nehemiah asks for official letters—a sign of legitimate authority and orderly government.

verses.text: and a letter to Asaph, the keeper of the king’s forest, that he may give me timber to make beams for the gates of the fortress by the temple, for the wall of the city, and for the house I shall occupy.' And the king granted me what I asked, for the good hand of my God was upon me.
verses.comment: God’s providence is emphasized. The mention of the temple’s fortress links the work directly with worship and spiritual defense.

verses.text: Then I came to the governors of the province Beyond the River and gave them the king’s letters. Now the king had sent with me officers of the army and horsemen.
verses.comment: The king’s military escort signifies the seriousness of Nehemiah’s mission, foreshadowing divine protection for those working for God’s people.

verses.text: But when Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite servant heard this, it displeased them greatly that someone had come to seek the good of the people of Israel.
verses.comment: Enemies of God's people immediately oppose restoration efforts; spiritual restoration always faces opposition (see Rev. 12:17).

verses.text: So I came to Jerusalem and was there three days.
verses.comment: Three days: a period of preparation and anticipation common in Scripture (see Josh. 1:11; Jonah 1:17; the resurrection in Matt. 12:40).

verses.text: I rose in the night, I and a few men with me. I told no one what my God had put into my heart to do for Jerusalem. There was no animal with me except the one I rode.
verses.comment: God initiates the restoration, working through humble means and secret planning—a spiritual principle throughout both Testaments.

verses.text: I went out by night through the Valley Gate, to the Dragon Spring and to the Dung Gate, and I inspected the walls of Jerusalem that were broken down and its gates that had been destroyed by fire.
verses.comment: Nehemiah inspects thorough the gates—symbolic of vigilance in rebuilding not only physical but also spiritual defense.

verses.text: Then I went on to the Fountain Gate and to the King’s Pool, but there was no room for the animal under me to pass.
verses.comment: The ‘King’s Pool’ refers to Hezekiah’s tunnel, tying Israel’s past faithfulness to the present rebuilding.

verses.text: So I went up by night along the valley and inspected the wall. Then I turned back and entered by the Valley Gate, and so returned.
verses.comment: Night-time vigilance denotes the wisdom of prudence in spiritual leadership—acting with care before widespread proclamation.

verses.text: The officials did not know where I had gone or what I was doing, and I had not yet told the Jews, the priests, the nobles, the officials, or the rest who were to do the work.
verses.comment: Nehemiah includes priests and nobles; godly restoration always involves spiritual leaders and laity working together.

verses.text: Then I said to them, 'You see the trouble we are in, how Jerusalem lies in ruins with its gates burned. Come, let us rebuild the wall of Jerusalem, that we may no longer suffer disgrace.'
verses.comment: Nehemiah calls for communal action—a theme of God’s people working collectively for restoration and overcoming disgrace.

verses.text: And I told them of the hand of my God that had been good upon me, and also the words that the king had spoken to me. So they said, 'Let us rise up and build.' So they strengthened their hands for the good work.
verses.comment: ‘The hand of my God’—divine providence and human cooperation. The unity in response foreshadows the unity called for in the New Testament Church.

verses.text: But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite servant, and Geshem the Arab heard it, they mocked us and despised us, saying, 'What is this thing you are doing? Are you rebelling against the king?'
verses.comment: Opposition is often accompanied by accusation and scorn. The pattern of false accusations against God’s people continues into the New Testament (Acts 24:5).

verses.text: Then I answered them, 'The God of heaven will cause us to prosper, and we his servants will arise and build; but you have no portion or right or memorial in Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: Only those who truly belong may share in God’s work—an early type of the united, visible covenant community, echoing Christ’s words of Church unity (John 17:21).
